newsitem.title: UK: FKI questions Newman Tonks defence.
newsitem.headline: FKI questions Newman Tonks defence.

text.p: Acquisitive British engineering group FKI Plc said on Monday it doubted the ability of the existing management at bid target Newman Tonks, a building equipment and engineering group, to deliver promised growth.

In an acid response to Newman Tonks defence document, published earlier today, FKI chairman Jeff Whalley said in a statement, "Yet again Newman Tonks is asking its shareholders to have faith in a failed management".
Whalley argued that the target company's mergers and acquisitions record over the last seven years gave little grounds for optimism, while FKI offered better performance.
In December FKI launched a 195.7 million pound hostile bid that it says provides a 46.9 percent capital uplift for Newman Tonks' shareholders.
In its defence, Tonks said the bid failed to reflect its international development, brand strength, order book or restructuring.

"The reality behind Newman Tonks' restructuring is that management has bought and sold businesses without any underlying strategic logic and, above all, has operated its retained businesses badly," FKI's Whalley said in his statement.
"How Newman Tonks' board can say that it has delivered a strong financial performance when earnings per share have fallen substantially over the past five years, is simply incredible."
